title: Chief Executive of Hong Kong
text:
The Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China is the representative of the <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a> <a href="Special%20administrative%20regions%20of%20China">Special Administrative Region</a> and <a href="head%20of%20government">head</a> of the <a href="Government%20of%20Hong%20Kong">Government of Hong Kong</a>. The position was created to replace the office of <a href="governor%20of%20Hong%20Kong">governor of Hong Kong</a>, the representative of the <a href="monarchy%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">monarch of the United Kingdom</a> during <a href="British%20Hong%20Kong">British rule</a>. The office, stipulated by the <a href="Hong%20Kong%20Basic%20Law">Hong Kong Basic Law</a>, formally came into being on 1 July 1997 when the <a href="transfer%20of%20the%20sovereignty%20of%20Hong%20Kong">sovereignty of Hong Kong was transferred</a> from the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> to the <a href="China">People's Republic of China</a>.
The functions of the chief executive include nominating <a href="Principal%20officials%20of%20Hong%20Kong">principal officials</a> for appointment by the <a href="State%20Council%20of%20the%20People%E2%80%99s%20Republic%20of%20China">Central People's Government of China</a> (State Council), which is headed by the <a href="Premier%20of%20the%20People%27s%20Republic%20of%20China">premier</a>, conducting <a href="Foreign%20relations%20of%20Hong%20Kong">foreign relations</a>, appointing judges and other public officers, giving consent to legislation passed by the <a href="Legislative%20Council%20of%20Hong%20Kong">Legislative Council</a>, and bestowing honours. The Basic Law grants the chief executive a wide range of powers, but obliges him or her, before making important policy decisions, introducing bills to the <a href="Legislative%20Council%20of%20Hong%20Kong">Legislative Council</a>, making subsidiary legislation, and dissolving the Legislative Council, to act only after consultation with the <a href="Executive%20Council%20of%20Hong%20Kong">Executive Council</a> (all of whose members are the CE's own appointees). The Executive Council consists of official and non-official members, including the <a href="chief%20secretary%20for%20administration">chief secretary for administration</a>, the most senior official and head of the <a href="Government%20Secretariat%20%28Hong%20Kong%29">Government Secretariat</a>, in charge of overseeing the administration of the Government.
The chief executive holds the title "<a href="The%20Honourable">The Honourable</a>", and ranks first in the <a href="Hong%20Kong%20order%20of%20precedence">Hong Kong order of precedence</a>. The official residence of the chief executive is <a href="Government%20House%2C%20Hong%20Kong">Government House</a> in <a href="Central%2C%20Hong%20Kong">Central</a>, <a href="Hong%20Kong%20Island">Hong Kong Island</a>.
The current chief executive is <a href="Carrie%20Lam">Carrie Lam</a>, who was <a href="2017%20Hong%20Kong%20Chief%20Executive%20election">selected</a> on 26 March 2017, appointed by the <a href="State%20Council%20of%20the%20People%E2%80%99s%20Republic%20of%20China">Central People's Government</a> with the State Council Decree signed by Premier <a href="Li%20Keqiang">Li Keqiang</a>, on 11 April 2017 and took office on 1 July 2017. She is the first woman to serve as Chief Executive.
Eligibility for office.
According to article 44 of the Basic Law, the chief executive must be a Chinese citizen as defined by the HKSAR Passports Ordinance. The individual must be at least 40 years old, a <a href="Hong%20Kong%20resident">Hong Kong permanent resident</a> who is a <a href="Nationality%20law%20of%20the%20People%27s%20Republic%20of%20China">Chinese citizen</a> with <a href="right%20of%20abode%20in%20Hong%20Kong">right of abode in Hong Kong</a>, and has ordinarily resided in Hong Kong for a continuous period of not less than 20 years. Article 47 further requires that the chief executive be a person of integrity, dedicated to his or her duties. In addition, since 2012, candidates may not stand for selection by the <a href="Election%20Committee">Election Committee</a> without first obtaining 150 nominations from its members.
Selection.
The chief executive is selected from a <a href="2014%20NPCSC%20Decision%20on%20Hong%20Kong">restricted pool</a> of candidates supportive of the Central Government by a 1200-member <a href="Election%20Committee">Election Committee</a>, an <a href="electoral%20college">electoral college</a> consisting of individuals (i.e. private citizens) and bodies (i.e. special interest groups) selected or elected within 28 <a href="Functional%20constituency%20%28Hong%20Kong%29">functional constituencies</a>, as prescribed in Annex I to the Basic Law. In the <a href="1996%20Hong%20Kong%20Chief%20Executive%20election">first selection</a> of the chief executive, the committee consisted of only 400 members. It was expanded to 800 for the <a href="2002%20Hong%20Kong%20Chief%20Executive%20election">second term</a>. As a result of enabling legislation stemming from a <a href="Consultation%20Document%20on%20the%20Methods%20for%20Selecting%20the%20Chief%20Executive%20and%20for%20Forming%20the%20LegCo%20in%202012">public consultation in 2010</a>, and its approval by the National People's Congress Standing Committee in Beijing, the number of representatives was increased from 800 to 1200.
The functional constituencies correspond to various sectors of the economy and society, each of which hold their own internal procedures to select electors. The chosen chief executive must be appointed by the <a href="State%20Council%20of%20the%20People%E2%80%99s%20Republic%20of%20China">Central People's Government</a> before taking office.
According to <a href="Hong%20Kong%20Basic%20Law%20Article%2046">article 46</a> the term of office of the chief executive is five years with a maximum of two consecutive terms. If a vacancy occurs mid-term, the new chief executive's first term is for the remainder of the previous chief executive's term only. The method of selecting the chief executive is provided under <a href="Hong%20Kong%20Basic%20Law%20Article%2045">Article 45</a> and Annex I of the Basic Law, and the Chief Executive Election Ordinance.
Winning candidates in the chief executive election publicly disaffiliate with a political party within seven days of the election and must not become a member of a party during their term of office.
Term of office.
Duties and powers.
Under the Basic Law the chief executive is the chief representative of the <a href="Hongkonger">people of Hong Kong</a> and is the <a href="head%20of%20the%20government">head of the government</a> of Hong Kong. The chief executive's powers and functions include leading the government, implementing the law, signing bills and budgets passed by the <a href="Legislative%20Council%20of%20Hong%20Kong">Legislative Council</a>, deciding on government policies, advising appointment and dismissal of principal officials of the <a href="Government%20of%20Hong%20Kong">Government of Hong Kong</a> to the <a href="State%20Council%20of%20the%20People%E2%80%99s%20Republic%20of%20China">Central People's Government</a> (State Council), appointing judges and holders of certain public offices and to pardon or <a href="commutation%20of%20sentence">commute</a> sentences. The position is also responsible for the <a href="Policy%20address%20of%20Hong%20Kong">policy address</a> made to the public.
The chief exeutive's powers and functions are established by article 48 of the Basic Law.
The <a href="Executive%20Council%20of%20Hong%20Kong">Executive Council of Hong Kong</a> is an organ for assisting the chief executive in policy-making. The council is consulted before making important policy decisions, introducing bills to the Legislative Council, making subordinate legislation or dissolving the Legislative Council.
Resignation.
Article 52 stipulates circumstances under which the chief executive must resign. Examples include the loss of ability to discharge his or her duties or refusal to sign a bill passed by a two-thirds majority of the Legislative Council.
Acting and succession.
The acting and succession line is spelled out in article 53. If the chief executive is not able to discharge his or her duties for short periods (such as during overseas visits), the duties would be assumed by the <a href="Chief%20Secretary%20for%20Administration%20of%20Hong%20Kong">chief secretary for administration</a>, the <a href="Financial%20Secretary%20of%20Hong%20Kong">financial secretary</a> or the <a href="secretary%20for%20justice">secretary for justice</a>, by rotation, in that order, as acting chief executive. In case the position becomes vacant, a new chief executive would have to be selected.
Residence and office.
Prior to the handover in 1997, the office of the chief executive-designate was at the 7th floor of the Asia Pacific Finance Tower. When <a href="Tung%20Chee-hwa">Tung Chee-hwa</a> assumed duty on 1 July 1997, the office of the chief executive was located at the fifth floor of the <a href="Former%20Central%20Government%20Offices">Former Central Government Offices</a> (Main Wing). In the past the governor had his office at Government House. Tung did not use <a href="Government%20House%2C%20Hong%20Kong">Government House</a> as the primary residence because he lived at his own residence at <a href="Grenville%20House">Grenville House</a>. <a href="Donald%20Tsang">Donald Tsang</a> decided to return to the renovated Government House during his <a href="First%20term%20of%20Donald%20Tsang%20as%20Chief%20Executive%20of%20Hong%20Kong">first term</a>, and moved in on 12 January 2006, for both his office and residence. In 2011, the office of the chief executive moved to the low block of the new <a href="Central%20Government%20Complex">Central Government Complex</a> in Tamar. <a href="Government%20House%2C%20Hong%20Kong">Government House</a> continues to serve as the official residence of the chief executive.
Former chief executives.
Upon retirement, former chief executives have access to office space at the Office of Former Chief Executives, 28 <a href="Kennedy%20Road%2C%20Hong%20Kong">Kennedy Road</a>. The office provides administrative support to former chief executives to perform promotional, protocol-related, or any other activities in relation to their former official role. The activities include receiving visiting dignitaries and delegations, giving local and overseas media interviews, and taking part in speaking engagements. A chauffeur-driven car is provided to discharge promotional and protocol-related functions.
Depending on police risk assessment, personal security protection is provided. Former chief executives also enjoy medical and dental care.
Former chief executives hold the title "The Honourable", and ranks third in the <a href="Hong%20Kong%20order%20of%20precedence">Hong Kong order of precedence</a>.
Remuneration.
Remuneration for the chief executive of Hong Kong is <a href="List%20of%20salaries%20of%20heads%20of%20state%20and%20government">among the highest in the world for a political leader</a>, and only second to that of the <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Singapore">Prime Minister of Singapore</a>. The pay level took a cue from the handsome amounts paid to the city's colonial governors – worth $273,000 per annum plus perks in 1992.
In 2005, <a href="Tung%20Chee%20Hwa">Tung Chee Hwa</a> received some HK$3 million ($378,500) in pay as chief executive. From 2009 until the end of 2014, the salary for the job stood at HK$4.22 million. In January 2015, CY Leung reversed a pay freeze imposed in 2012, resulting in its increase to HK$4.61 million ($591,000). In July 2017, Directors of Bureaux (DoBs) were approved to have a 12.4% pay rise and the 3.5% pay differential between Secretaries of Departments (SoDs) and DoBs remained, indicating a new annual pay of approximately HK$5 million for the city's leading role because the chief executive received a salary of 112% of the <a href="Chief%20Secretary%20for%20Administration">chief secretary</a>. The new salary of the chief executive of Hong Kong is about thirty-nine times more than the current annual salary of the <a href="President%20of%20the%20People%27s%20Republic%20of%20China">President of China</a>.
Criticism of the office.
Since the chief executive is directly appointed by the Central People's Government after an election by a committee of 1,200 people selected by the Central People's Government, rather than the general population, many people, in particular the <a href="pro-democracy%20camp">pro-democrats</a>, have criticised the office as undemocratic, and have criticised the entire election process as a "small-circle election." Former Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa has even stated that the election's result is a non-binding one.
<a href="Democratic%20development%20in%20Hong%20Kong">Many events</a>, including 2010 events such as the <a href="Five%20Constituencies%20Referendum">Five Constituencies Referendum</a> have attempted to push for greater democracy and <a href="universal%20suffrage">universal suffrage</a>.
In January 2015, when CY Leung reversed a pay freeze imposed on the chief executive and senior civil servants in 2012, he was accused of granting himself a pay rise by stealth and going against the trend of top politicians taking pay cuts instead of pay increases.
